resources.string: nRF Connect (formerly known as nRF Master Control Panel) is a powerful generic tool that allows you to scan for Bluetooth Low Energy devices and communicate with them. nRF Connect supports a number of Bluetooth SIG adopted profiles as well as the Device Firmware Update profile (DFU) from Nordic Semiconductor.

You have cloned the advertising packet of a device. However, the Android API does not allow for a full customization of the data. For example, if the Complete Local Name is set, it will use the phone\'s name. The TX Power Level will have the actual TX power level. Flags are added automatically by the system and the Appearance can\'t be set. Additionally, due to an Android bug, advertising data and the scan response data may have just a single instance of Service Data and Manufacturer Data per packet. \n\nFind your newly cloned packet in the ADVERTISER tab.
Caution: Android may truncate this UUID to a 16-bit UUID.
The table of Bluetooth SIG members Company Identifiers may be found here: https://www.bluetooth.org/en-us/specification/assigned-numbers/company-identifiers
S130 alpha released \nNordic flagship Bluetooth Low Energy protocol stack enables sophisticated wearable hub networks with sensors that don\'t need smartphones.
This feature is not supported\non your device.
You may export and import user defined names from the Definitions screen available in the menu.
Please, provide a new display name:
Please, provide a new display name for selected characteristic:
Please, provide a new display name for selected service:

This screen lists all UUIDs definitions created by the user, adopted by Bluetooth SIG and other parties known to nRF Connect. You may export the definitions to a nRF Connect for Desktop compatible JSON file and import on another device or PC. \n\nTo rename an unknown service or characteristic, connect to a device, long tap the row and select EDIT in the menu, or import a new definitions file.
Click a blue device icon on the Scanner view to add the device to favorites.
How to mark a device as favorite?

Hello! We\'ve noticed you connected to micro:bit.\nClick the Macros button below. In the micro:bit Demo folder you\'ll find some nice new macros to play with. Observe the LED matrix. Sometimes you\'ll have to press a button as well. Enjoy!
* Only the payload and CRC use 500 kbps.

Hello! You connected to your Thingy:52 for the first time.
Click the Macros button below. In the Thingy Demo folder you'll find some nice new macros to play with. Some of them work better with the LOOP enabled. Enjoy!

Don't use them on airplanes or other public places as it may cause panic!
This value does not match its type.
This value must have even number of characters.
Enter the RSSI value to calibrate distance estimation. Typical values are in range from -73 to -60 dBm.
Enter the beacon advertising interval in milliseconds (100 – 10240 ms).
Please provide the new Major and Minor numbers of the Beacon.
Shows notifications when new files has been saved.
Displays a notification about the running service.
Shows a notification when new Bluetooth LE connection has been established and nRF Connect is in background.
Shows a notification when Link Loss service was set up and the connected Proximity device went out of range.
File browser application has not been found on your device. Would you like to download one?

Do you want to select the Init packet file?\n The Init packet file (*.dat) should contain the device type and revision, application version, list of supported Soft Devices and the firmware CRC in binary format or, with old versions of the DFU bootloader, only the CRC (CRC-CCITT-16). With the new version of the bootloader the extended Init packet is required.
You must select a valid HEX, BIN or ZIP file.
You must select a valid DAT file.
Unable to obtain file location. Please, use another application to select file.
Provide number of packets of firmware data to be received by the DFU Target before it needs to send a Packets Receipt Notification. Setting it to 0 will disabled these notifications:
DFU script files were copied to /sdcard/Nordic Semiconductor.

Starting from nRF Connect v3.0 the new Distribution packet (ZIP) is the recommended method for distributing firmware upgrades. You can create the ZIP file using the nrf utility tool, which is part of Master Control Panel 3.8.0+. For more detailed information, see the DFU documentation. 

Backward compatibility 
The nRF Connect also supports all old file formats: HEX and BIN files, separate DAT files and ZIP files without a manifest file but with a fixed naming convention:

This dialog allows you to bind the EID configuration from the current slot with a custom name. When done, the nRF Connect application will be able to resolve the beacon\'s EID packet to the given name.
Factory reset. All slots will be erased!
Pairing failed. See log for details.
Loading file has failed. Try different file browser app.
Data too long to copy to clipboard. Try saving them in a file.

Do you want to save the log session?

for maximum (ms, 0 or empty value = no timeout):

Macro or a folder with this name already exists.
Name must not have <, >, &, \", \' or \\ characters.
You must select a valid BIN file.
Tap to switch to selecting a day
Tap to switch to selecting a year
Web Browser application is not available.
No flags in the advertisement data.

Your phone may require the Location service to be enabled in order to scan for Bluetooth LE devices. If you are sure that there are devices advertising in range and you don\'t see them here, enable it. You may restrict other applications from knowing your location by denying them Location permission in Android Settings.
There is no application that can open this URI.

Do you want to debug the connection?

Hint:
You are seeing this notification because nRF Connect is running in background.
Do you want to debug the connection?
nRF Connect is running in background
Allows the app to write and read from Nordic Semiconductor Event log
If you enjoy using this app, please take a moment and rate it or write a comment.\nThanks for you support!

Starting from Android 6.0 Marshmallow the system requires location permission in order to scan for Bluetooth LE devices. \n\nBluetooth beacons, like iBeacons or Eddystone beacons, may be used to determine the phone\'s and user\'s location. This application is not using this information in any way.
LEN. - length of EIR packet (Type + Data) in bytes,\nTYPE - the data type as in https://www.bluetooth.org/en-us/specification/assigned-numbers/generic-access-profile
Do you want to reset the device to bootloader?
At least one property must be set.
Please, provide a unique configuration name:

Select one of the configured services to add a service with fully implemented behaviour. With a custom service you will be able to manually set characteristic and descriptors data and send notifications. Start typing the service name to automatically fill the UUID.
There are no services to be cloned.
GATT server disabled.\n\nSelect configuration to enable.
Server configuration with this name already exists.

DFU documentation on Nordic\'s Developer Zone

Check this switch to ON if you want to perform a DFU operation without jumping to the bootloader mode on a device with a DFU implementation from SDK 6.1 or older. To achieve the same result on any newer legacy DFU implementation the DFU Version characteristic should return value other than 0x0100.

During a DFU operation a lot of data packets are being sent to the target. The onCharacteristicWrite(...) callback in Android API is invoked when the data has been written to the outgoing queue, not when physically sent. Packet receipt notifications were introduced to prevent from overflowing the queue. Depending on the device model, disabling the notifications or setting the value to “high” (> ~300) may make the DFU process freeze at some point.
Log sessions may be stored and viewed using the nRF Logger application.
Please, restart the application to apply changes.
Offloaded scan batching has been disabled.

Offloaded scan batching may cause errors during the calculation of advertising intervals. Some devices report every batch twice (the second one is ignored). Additionally, if has been found, that Samsung S6 always returns the same RSSI values for all devices if this option is enabled.

Some devices, f.e. Nexus 4 or Nexus 7, notifies about connectible peripherals (where SCAN REQUEST and SCAN RESPONSE are used) only once per scan. With continuous mode disabled scanner will stop and start scanning again every two seconds to get RSSI values from those devices. Please note that it is not possible to estimate the advertising interval in such case.
Selected device supports Device Firmware Update profile. Click the DFU button above to upload new application onto the device.
Now you may save the device advertising data to a file or export RSSI values to CSV or Excel format.
Scroll the list to the right in order to show the signal strength graph.
Some connections are still open. Click YES to close all and exit.
Download nRF Logger to see progress
